sect1.title: Overview
sect1.para: This specification gives direction on how to name the sounds that are available for use by applications, when creating a sound theme. It does so by laying out a standard naming scheme for sound creation, as well as providing a minimal list of must have sounds, and a larger list with many more examples to help with the creation of extended sounds for third party applications, with different event types and usage.

sect1.title: Context
sect1.para: The list of default Contexts for the sound theme are:

row.entry: Sounds to alert the user of an action or event which may have a major imact on the system or their current use case, such as dialog-error.
Sounds to notify the user that the system, or their current use case has changed state in some way, e.g. new email arriving, new non-critical update available...
Sounds that give the user feedback on their actions. Sounds on window opening / closing for example.

sect1.title: Sound Naming Guidelines
sect1.para:
Here we define some guidelines for when creating new sounds that extend the standardized list of sound names defined here, in order to provide sounds for more specific events and usages.
Sound names are in the en_US.US_ASCII locale. This means that the allowable characters in the sound names, must fall withing the US-ASCII character set. As a further restriction, all sound names may only contain lowercase letters, numbers, underscore, dash, or period characters. Spaces, colons, slashes, and backslashes are not allowed. Also, sound names must be spelled as they are in the en_US dictionary.
The dash - character is used to separate levels of specificity in sound names. For instance, we use search-results as the generic item for all mouse devices, and we use search-results-empty for a USB mouse device. However, if the more specific item does not exist in the current theme, and does exist in a parent theme, the generic sound from the current theme is preferred, in order to keep consistent style.
Sounds for branded applications should be named the same as the binary executable for the application.

sect1.title: Standard Sounds Names
sect1.para: This section describes the standard sounds names that should be used by artists when creating themes, and by developers when writing applications which will use the Sound Theme Specification.

sect2.title: Alerts
sect2.para: This is to notify the user of an action or event which may have a major imact on the system or their current use case.

row.entry: The sound used when an error occurs trying to intialize the network connection of the computing device.
The sound used when a dialog is opened to explain an error condition to the user.
The sound used when the battery is low (below 20%, for example).
The sound used when an urgent update is available through the system software update program.

sect2.title: Notifications
sect2.para: This is to alert the user that the system, or their current use case has changed state in some way - mew email arriving, new non-critical update to an application available.

row.entry: The sound used when one or more search results are returned.
The sound used when no search results are returned.
The sound used when the user locks their current session.
The sound used when a user logs into the system or a service (i.e. desktop login)
The sound used when a user logs out of the system or a service (i.e. Gaim logout)
The sound used when the battery is (below 40%, for example).
The sound used when a dialog is opened to give information to the user that may be pertinent to the requested action.
The sound used when an update is available for software installed on the computing device, through the system software update program.

sect2.title: Support
sect2.para: This is to alert the user that the system, or their current use case has changed state in some way - mew email arriving, new non-critical update to an application available.

row.entry: The sound used when a new IM or email is recieved.
The sound used when a new IM or email is sent.
The sound used when a new window or dialog is opened.
The sound used when an existing window is closed.
The sound used for the OK button that might appear in dialog windows.
The sound used for the Cancel button that might appear in dialog windows.
The sound used when a file is accepted by a window, such as a folder or IM conversation.
The sound used when the user emptys the trash.
The sound used when a file or folder is sent to the trash.

sect2.title: Game
sect2.para: This is to alert the user that the system, or their current use case has changed state in some way - mew email arriving, new non-critical update to an application available.

sect1.title: Background
sect1.para: The sound naming specification is heavily based on the "Icon Naming Specification" by Rodney Dawes and the "Bango Project" started by Jon Bolt.
